dlgPart.npc_text: You enter the main hall. At the far end of it, Lord Gaelius holds court, receiving daily visitors in the order of their importance. A row of guards form a barrier between the Lord of the House and the petitioners, with blank stares on their faces. Another row forms a semi-circle around Gaelius, their eyes constantly scanning the crowd.

dlgAnsw.text: Approach.

dlgPart.npc_text:
The spy quickly explains the situation to the Legatus, while Lord Gaelius listens carefully, glancing in your direction. He asks the Legatus something before gesturing for you to approach.
“I’m not sure what to do with you,” says Gaelius. “You’ve served my cause, yet the only name you’ve made for yourself is that of a traitor. I’m grateful for your interference, but if you expect more than that, you’d better be prepared to prove yourself. Are you up for it?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Yes, my lord.”
“I’ve done enough.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text:
You give Gaelius the document and step back, waiting patiently. He looks at you for a moment, then unfolds the scroll and starts reading. When he’s done, he looks at you once again, pondering something.
“You haven’t heard then,” he says with a friendly smile. “This alliance is what everyone’s talking about. Carrinas needs legitimacy and he would never keep Antidas’ backing a secret. I’m sorry, my friend, but this paper has no value.
“Still, you’ve risked much to bring it to me and that’s worth something, isn’t it? I’ll give you a chance to prove yourself, if you are up for it.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Yes, my lord.”
“I’ve done enough.” Leave.

“You haven’t heard of Zamedi? Now that is a cautionary tale, if there ever was one. It is said that during the war the town of Zamedi was under siege for almost a year. The walls were impregnable – granite infused with magic. And so it stood until our Magi came up with a siege engine of immense power. They assured the Emperor that it will have no problem blasting through the walls and they didn’t lie. The siege engine obliterated the walls, the town with all the defenders, and our army that was ready to charge into the breach, leaving nothing but a tower.
“The desert where Zamedi used to be was glowing at night for decades, killing anyone who’d come close.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you want me to do?”
“How did the tower survive the attack?”
“Is it safe now?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I don't know. The mere fact that it did was enough for us to seal it and leave it alone.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you want me to do?”
“Is it safe now?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “After so many years? It’s quite safe, I assure you. The magic is long gone.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you want me to do?”
“How did the tower survive the attack?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “There is an old tomb south-east of here, too far from any town, but close enough to the road to Ganezzar. It’s been a raiders’ den for years. Every now and then we clear them out, but they always come back. It’s too good of a spot, I suppose.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Do you want me to deal with them?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“If it comes to it,” says Gaelius graciously, “but that’s not why I’m sending you there. Have you heard about the Helm of Destiny?
“It’s an ancient helmet, reputedly one of great power. Self-proclaimed lord Darius, a famous warlord who lived two hundred years ago, was given the helmet as a tribute. After donning it, he’d swiftly risen to prominence and won every battle he fought - or so the legends claim. He built a large army and eventually laid siege to Ganezzar. They say that he was quite mad at that point, frequently speaking to himself and giving strange orders.”

onLoadScripts.string: dlgAddTextBoxMessage("Darius Tomb added to the map");

dlgAnsw.text: “What happened then?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“House Crassus paid the Boatmen a fortune and they did what no army could. Lord Darius died in horrible convulsions, foaming at the mouth, the siege was broken, and the helmet disappeared.
“As the story goes, Darius’ men buried their lord where his rest wouldn’t be disturbed. Since all attempts to find his tomb have failed, his men definitely succeeded in their task.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Until now.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Unfortunately,” says Gaelius. “I would sleep much better knowing that the Helm of Destiny was lost forever, but apparently, a good night’s sleep has become something of a luxury these days.
“My loremaster has dug out an interesting document - the will of one of Darius’ officers. He lists his property, divides it amongst his children and retainers, and assigns different tasks, asking his children to look after the very tomb I’m sending you to.”

dlgAnsw.text: “They buried him there? In someone else’s tomb?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I think so. I can hardly imagine a better place to bury a great man than an old tomb that’s already been ransacked. It’s the last place anyone would think to look for him. So, I want you go there and take a look. If Darius has indeed been buried there, recover the helmet and bring it here with extreme caution.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why is it called the Helm of Destiny?”
“You mentioned that Darius was quite mad when he was killed.”
“If the helmet is there, I’ll find it.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “The legends say that it leads its wearer to glory, that it gives him a worthy destiny. While it’s tempting to dismiss such childish claims, Darius’ rise to power and glory does lend some credence to these tales.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Maybe he was a good general?”
“If the helmet is there, I’ll find it.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “Maybe, but by all accounts he was fairly mediocre until he put on that helmet. Now, I too believe that there is a reasonable and simple explanation, but I’m not the type of man to leave such things to chance. If the helmet played any role in Darius’ success, I want it found and put away for good.”

dlgAnsw.text: “You mentioned that Darius was quite mad when he was killed.”
“If the helmet is there, I’ll find it.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “So they say. He argued with himself, had sudden fits of rage, and often spoke words that nobody could understand. Sometimes he wouldn’t recognize his own men, but maybe that’s the price he paid for his brilliance on the battlefield.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why is it called the Helm of Destiny?”
“If the helmet is there, I’ll find it.” Leave.

“I’m sure you’ve heard about what happened in Teron. The Imperial Guards have finally shown their true colors. They are a snake, coiled to strike. The question is, do I wait until the last moment, becoming a prisoner in my own city, depending on goodwill of others, or do I take steps to defend myself and my city from those who’d take it away from me? I think you know the answer.
I need an army, <charname>, an army that will stand between me and the so-called Guards, an army that will stand firm between stability and chaos.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Where would you find an army?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “You don’t have to worry about it. I’ve already found my army - I made a deal with one of the Ordu tribes.”

onLoadScripts.string: dlgAddTextBoxMessage("The Pass added to the map");

dlgAnsw.text: “You’ll open your gates to the Ordu?”
“You think you can control them?”
“What do you want me to do?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I’ve already opened them to the Imperial Guards. The true enemy is already within my walls. Now, it’s time to even the scales. At worst, the Ordu will keep the Imperial Guards in check, while the Guards will keep the Ordu from running amok in my city. At best... ah, we all can dream, can we not?”

dlgAnsw.text: “You think you can control them?”
“What do you want me to do?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Why demonize the Ordu? They may be savages, but they are not fools. They will serve me and in exchange they will be well rewarded and granted certain advantages. Thus, when they fight, they won’t fight for me, but to protect their new way of life. Has there ever been a better reason to fight and die for?
“If you know the Ordu, then you know that only a dire necessity would force them to accept my offer. This necessity will keep them in line, and once they realize that living in the greatest city in the world is better than living in tents on the plains, they will be my most loyal soldiers, for nobody appreciates good things in life as someone who has started with nothing.”

dlgAnsw.text: “You’ll open your gates to the Ordu?”
“What do you want me to do?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I want you to bring them here. The Ordu should have been here a week ago, but they are stalling. Go to their encampment, find out what the problem is and fix it. Do it for me and you’ll be well rewarded.”

dlgAnsw.text: “You’ll open your gates to the Ordu?”
“You think you can control them?”
“I will, my lord.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “One more thing, <charname>. The only way to the Ordu’s camp lies through the Harran’s Pass. The pass is controlled by the Imperial Guards. If they suspect that you’re working for me, they’ll throw you off the mountain. Needless to say, it’s your best interest that they don’t.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What are they going to do when they see an approaching army?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “They will send for help and will try to delay you until the reinforcements get there. If they do, it’s over. The Ordu won’t stand a chance against a legion of veteran soldiers, holding high ground. So, whatever you’re going to do, do it fast.”

dlgAnsw.text: Leave.
